item.title: S&P 500 Is Near Session Lows on US-China Tension: Markets Wrap
item.description: A solid month for stocks is ending on a weak note as President Donald Trump said Beijing “totally violated” a tariff agreement, with the market extending losses on a news report the administration plans to broaden restrictions on China’s technology sector.
item.dc:creator: Rita Nazareth

item.title: Amazon’s AI Roadmap With AWS CEO Garman
item.description: Every aspect of Amazon is leveraging artificial intelligence, says Matt Garman, CEO of Amazon Web Services. Garman discuss Amazon’s AI roadmap and reflects on his first year in the role with Ed Ludlow on “Bloomberg Technology.” (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Google's Dominance at Risk As Monopoly Trial Concludes
item.description: Justin Teresi Bloomberg Intelligence's Antitrust Litigation & Policy Analyst joins to discuss closing arguments from the Google search case and how this trial could change the fate of search in the US. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Gold Slips as Dollar Edges Higher Amid US Data, Trade Tensions
item.description: Gold declined and the dollar advanced as traders assessed US data on consumer spending, the flow of imports and renewed trade tensions between America and China.
item.dc:creator: Yvonne Yue Li

media:content.media:description: Gold bullions at the YLG Bullion International Co. headquarters in Bangkok, Thailand, on Friday, Dec. 22, 2023. Gold headed for a weekly gain after US price data came in cooler than forecast, reinforcing expectations for multiple interest rate cuts by the Federal Reserve next year. Photographer: Chalinee Thirasupa/Bloomberg

item.title: European Gas Posts Monthly Gain as Supply Prospects Tighten
item.description: European natural gas posted its first monthly advance since January amid a flurry of geopolitical developments and signs of a tighter market.
item.dc:creator: Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: Gas burns on an oven hob.

item.title: Trump Media Raises $2.44 Billion for Bitcoin Treasury Plan
item.description: Trump Media & Technology Group Corp., the company behind Truth Social, raised around $1.44 billion from selling stock at a price of $25.72 per share and raised about $1 billion in convertible bonds, to buy Bitcoin for its treasury.
item.dc:creator: Monique Mulima

media:content.media:description: A cutout of US President Donald Trump holding a Bitcoin is displayed on a group of servers during The Bitcoin Conference at The Venetian Las Vegas in Las Vegas, Nevada, on May 27, 2025. (Photo by Ian Maule / AFP) (Photo by IAN MAULE/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Dollar’s Weekly Gain Looks Like a Blip as Pressures Mount
item.description: The best week for the dollar in three months isn’t enough to reverse its broader declines as US trade and policy uncertainty weighs on sentiment.
item.dc:creator: Vassilis Karamanis, Anya Andrianova

media:content.media:description: A US dollar sign on a glass in the trading room at foreign exchange brokerage Gaitame.Com Co. in Tokyo, Japan, on Monday, June 24, 2024. The yen remained under pressure on Monday, even after Japan’s top currency official warned that authorities stand ready to intervene in currency markets 24 hours a day if necessary. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Supreme Court Clears Trump to Strip 500,000 of Legal Status
item.description: The Supreme Court allowed the Trump administration to immediately end temporary legal status for migrants from Cuba, Haiti, Nicaragua, and Venezuela, affecting up to half a million people. The court's order clears the way for the Department of Homeland Security to end so-called parole programs, which gave migrants temporary legal status, and marks the second time in less than two weeks the justices have opened hundreds of thousands of migrants to possible deportation. The decision was met with dissent from Justices Ketanji Brown Jackson and Sonia Sotomayor, who argued that the court "undervalues the devastating consequences of allowing the government to precipitously upend the lives and livelihoods of nearly half a million noncitizens while their legal claims are pending." Bloomberg's Greg Stohr reports. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Ukraine to Skip $665 Million Payment on Growth-Linked Debt
item.description: Ukraine said it’s skipping a $665 million payment on government debt linked to economic growth after the country failed to agree on restructuring terms with a group of creditors led by hedge funds.
item.dc:creator: Daryna Krasnolutska

item.title: US Posted Record Oil Output Before Price Dip Spurred Rig Retreat
item.description: US drillers pumped a record amount of oil in March, but the final number came in lower than government figures previously indicated.
item.dc:creator: Lucia Kassai

media:content.media:description: A pumpjack operates in the Permian Basin near Orla, Texas.

item.title: S&P 500 Declines With Renewed Trade Tensions Dampening Sentiment
item.description: US stocks fell on Friday as President Donald Trump accused China of violating an agreement with the US to ease tariffs, renewing tensions between the White House and Beijing.
item.dc:creator: Alexandra Semenova

item.title: US Tax on Foreign Money Is Power Play, Commerzbank Analyst Says
item.description: A proposed measure in Donald Trump’s flagship tax-and-spending bill is a sign that the US administration is exploring new tools to force other countries to bend to its will, according to Ulrich Leuchtmann, head of FX research at Commerzbank AG.
item.dc:creator: Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: The White House in Washington, DC, US, on Saturday, May 10, 2025. The legislative push for President Donald Trump's massive tax package will begin in earnest next week as key House committees consider the legislation despite lingering divisions among Republicans.

item.title: Brookfield Eyes $3 Billion in Debt for Colonial Pipeline
item.description: Brookfield Asset Management Ltd. is lining up approximately $3 billion in debt financing to support its purchase of Colonial Enterprises, which operates the Colonial Pipeline in the US, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Aaron Weinman, Chunzi Xu

media:content.media:description: Storage tanks at a Colonial Pipeline Inc. facility in Avenel, New Jersey, U.S., on Wednesday, May 12, 2021. Motorists across a broad swath of the U.S. East Coast and South are struggling to find gasoline and diesel as filling stations run dry amid the unprecedented pipeline disruption caused by a criminal hack. Photographer: Mark Kauzlarich/Bloomberg

item.title: European Stocks Post Best Month Since January With Eyes on Trade
item.description: European stocks notched their biggest monthly gain since January as investors monitored the outlook for global trade.
item.dc:creator: Sagarika Jaisinghani

media:content.media:description: The Euronext stock exchange in Paris. Photographer: Nathan Laine/Bloomberg

item.title: Rich Nations Courted by Zimbabwe Non-Committal on $2.6 Billion Bridge Finance
item.description: Zimbabwe hasn’t received any concrete commitments of financial support from 10 nations it appealed to for help in its long-standing efforts to clear debt arrears.
item.dc:creator: Katarina Hoije, Ray Ndlovu

media:content.media:description: Mthuli Ncube, Zimbabwe's finance minister, during a panel session at the World Economic Forum (WEF) in Davos, Switzerland, on Wednesday, Jan. 22, 2025. The annual Davos gathering of political leaders, top executives and celebrities runs from January 20 to 24.

item.title: 49ers Expand Sporting Empire to Buy Scotland’s Rangers FC
item.description: Rangers Football Club, one of two giants in Scottish football, has been bought out by an American consortium of 49ers Enterprises and health entrepreneur Andrew Cavenagh.
item.dc:creator: David Hellier

media:content.media:description: A Rangers flag outside inbox Stadium in Glasgow Scotland.

item.title: Trump Tariff Reprieve; Gaza Ceasefire Proposal | Horizons Middle East & Africa 05/30/2025
item.description: A federal appeals court has temporarily blocked a ruling that threatened to throw out the bulk of President Donald Trump's tariff agenda. Also on the show: Trump pushed Fed Chair Jerome Powell to cut rates at their first in-person meeting since his inauguration; the White House says a Gaza ceasefire proposal has been submitted to Hamas; defense ministers and senior military figures are in Singapore for the annual Shangri-La Dialogue; oil is set for its second weekly decline ahead of OPEC+ meeting; the US is considering a deal with Rwanda to accept deportees; Google and the US Department of Justice are slated to offer closing arguments in an antitrust case. Guests include: Ozan Özkural, Tanto Capital Partners, Founder & Managing Partner; Livia Gallarati, Energy Aspects, Global Crude Lead. (Video has been edited to remove reporter misstatement of figure during story on Africa Development Bank.) (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: First Abu Dhabi Bank Shareholder Offers $480 Million Stake
item.description: A shareholder in First Abu Dhabi Bank PJSC plans to sell a roughly 1% stake in the UAE-based bank, exiting its position in the lender.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel

media:content.media:description: A First Abu Dhabi Bank branch and office building in Abu Dhabi, United Arab Emirates.

item.title: Gap CEO on Retail Pain
item.description: Gap is predicting a tariff impact of as much as $300 million, and revealed stubborn weakness at two of its smaller brands, Banana Republic and Athleta. The company's CEO Richard Dickson joined Bloomberg Open Interest to talk about the weak quarter. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: NetEase Shares Near Record High as China’s Gen Z Embraces Games
item.description: NetEase Inc. shares are closing in on their first new all-time high in over four years, as a wave of youthful consumerism adds to a host of positives for China’s game stocks.
item.dc:creator: Henry Ren, Sangmi Cha

item.title: China’s Startups Race to Dominate Humanoid Robot Market
item.description: Chinese startups are rapidly developing AI-powered humanoid robots for complex roles in factories, households, and schools. Their swift progress has drawn global attention — Elon Musk has even expressed concern that China may soon dominate the field. Bloomberg TV’s Annabelle Droulers explains. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: EchoStar Skips Bond Payment as FCC’s 5G Probe Heats Up
item.description: EchoStar Corp., the wireless and pay-TV operator controlled by billionaire Charlie Ergen, skipped an interest payment due Friday because of uncertainty about a regulatory probe.
item.dc:creator: Dorothy Ma, Molly Schuetz

media:content.media:description: EchoStar Corporation headquarters in Englewood, Colorado.

item.title: Saylor’s Contrarian Bet Morphs Into Full-Blown Crypto Gold Rush
item.description: TLGY Acquisition Corp. put a pitch in front of investors in April entitled “MicroStrategy 2.0,” a reference to the Bitcoin-accumulation company run by Michael Saylor. Only TLGY wasn’t planning to buy Bitcoin.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Weeks, Olga Kharif

item.title: Oil Falls on Expectation of Big OPEC+ Output Hike, Trade Jitters
item.description: Oil extended its weekly decline in choppy trading on heightened prospects of more supply from OPEC+ and as US President Donald Trump reignited trade tensions with China.
item.dc:creator: Mia Gindis, Alex Longley

media:content.media:description: Fuel and crude oil storage tanks at the Galp Energia SGPS SA Sines refinery plant in Sines, Portugal, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. Galp expects its biofuels and green hydrogen projects located at the Sines refinery will be operating in mid-2026. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Cooking Gas Shortage in Cuba Fuels Electric Demand, Deepening Energy Crisis
item.description: Top Cuban officials took to the airwaves as a shortage of cooking gas on the communist-run island prompted an unusual spike in electricity demand that’s now exacerbating blackouts.
item.dc:creator: Jim Wyss

media:content.media:description: Residents use lights on their phone during a blackout in Havana on March 14. Photographer: Yamil Lage/AFP/Getty Images

item.title: ECB Steps Up Scrutiny of Banks’ Exposure to Private Markets
item.description: The European Central Bank is escalating its scrutiny of lenders’ exposures to private markets amid concerns that the fast ascent of related asset classes raises substantial new risks.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort, Esteban Duarte, Claudia Cohen, Jorge Zuloaga

item.title: US Consumer Sentiment Rebounds in Michigan Survey
item.description: US consumer sentiment recovered in late May as the 52.2 final sentiment index marked an improvement from the preliminary reading of 50.8, according to the University of Michigan. Consumers expect prices to rise 6.6% over the next year, up just modestly from the 6.5% seen a month earlier. Michael McKee reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: Morgan Stanley CIO Mike Wilson Weighs In on the AI Trade
item.description: "I don't agree that we are in a bubble," Morgan Stanley CIO Mike Wilson says while discussing AI stocks on "Bloomberg Open Interest." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: OPEC+ Mulls Even Larger Output Hike to Regain Market Share
item.description: OPEC+ is considering accelerating its production increases by discussing a potential hike of more than 411,000 barrels a day for July, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Salma El Wardany, Grant Smith, Sam Dagher

media:content.media:description: An oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia.
